overall_summary: The reasoning trajectory demonstrates a structured approach to time-series forecasting focused on handling short-term hourly data with daily seasonality. The analyst prioritizes simplicity due to limited historical data (only 4 days), opting for a pattern-based averaging method after evaluating and dismissing more complex models like SARIMA. Key considerations include handling potential missing values, assessing data stability, and accounting for time-based patterns while acknowledging limitations in capturing weekly seasonality.
common_data_patterns: Stable daily patterns with minor variations
Complete data in provided segment (no missing values)
Potential outliers (e.g., low value at hour 20 on day 3)
key_insights: Prioritizing simplicity when historical data is limited (4 days)
Hourly averaging effectively captures daily seasonality patterns
Explicit handling of timestamps and date sequencing for forecasting
Rounding outputs to match input precision (3 decimal places)
Acknowledging limitations in modeling weekly seasonality due to insufficient data
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex with practical constraints: Combines data inspection, method evaluation, and step-by-step implementation while consciously avoiding overcomplication. Balances statistical awareness (seasonality detection) with pragmatic execution given data limitations.
